content:
ICS 1C HW 2 for QQ Skeleton -- Heading

About QQ Skeleton

Name:Sandra Sosa
E-mail: easu1577@ea.oac.uci.edu
Major: Social Science; Spanish

Three neat Web finds:

  1. With the Web one can find information about a specific country without having to stress. If you are planning to travel or just inquire about a country the Virtual Tourist (by Brandon Plewe) is the place to visit. It serves as a visual interface into the geographic distribution of the WWW servers. It gathers tourism, geographical and cultural information about a specific region. All you have to do is click on a symbol or boxed region within the Mosaic page. click here to view! the available page.

  2. Traveling trough the world may be to exhausting for some. Maybe a more specific search is needed. The Web is the place to do it. The Yellow pages may sometimes lack the specific information we need about a particualr business. The list of Comercial Services on the Web and (Net) is available with lots of more detail. On this page dozzens of links to businesses, business service and nonprofit organizations are availabel. Take a look to see what you can find. click here!

    Here you can browse through the businesses you are interested in, get detail information and even order. For example, when click on the above, the page asks you to enter a search, you could enter the word flower and a list of florist will appear you may choose one or several and even order what you like.

  3. Businesses still have lot's of improvements comming up. There is a lot to look forward in the future. For example in the future we may be able to do our banking in our home computer. Bank of America has a home page that promises lot's of potential. All your transactions can be taken care of by clicking a few icons. Imagine no more waiting in line or dealing with tellers who are slow and don't know much. View Bank of America!

    We may be able to have it all. Now we can travel form our computers and learn about the different countries and specific reagions without spending money. In the future we may be able to do it all. From our banking need to shopping for groceries. Computers will become as necessary as a car.

Questions I can now answer
  1. What is the importance of the World Wide Web?
  2. What kind of information about Spain is available in the Web?
  3. How can you find interesting information in the field of social sciences?
  4. How can one create a page to view in Mosaic?
  5. Where can you find sources in Spanish to practice reading as well as learn about other places where the official language is spanish?
  1. What is the importance of the World Wide Web?

    Before this class I had no idea the web existed. Now I realize how much time I could have saved if I had known about it before. You can do research and get lots of updated information in less time than doing library research. But is not just beneficial for students, the web is fun for any user since you can explore items world wide. Most of the browsers are easy to use. A popular one is Mosaic, since it includes graphics is fun to work with. If one is interested in animal then you could access this article . This particular example is found in the Animal Rights Resource Site but it could also be from your next door neighbor since any one can create a document in the Web. The most amazing aspects of the Web is the ability to conect to computers around the world. I recently connected to Stockholm, Sweden and looked at the information they have on museums and the water festival. The most amazing graphics are available to view.

    Return to list of questions.

  2. What kind of information about Spain is available in the Web?

    Through the Web we could get a grasp about the culture in Spain. It tells us what Spain offers us as tourists and as students. In the Web we can learn what a great cultural center Spain is, especilly in literature a nd paintings. Men like Velazquez, Goya, Quevedo and Cervantes got their inspiration in this country. Books mainly talk about the history and that is sometimes boring. In the Web I learned that looking things up can be fun because most of the information is current and interactive. By clicking on a map of Spain you could get information on a specific region. For example Spain the home page offers you different e-mail addresses to establish correspondance with someone in the universities there. What a better way to get hands on information about the style of life the Spaniards live. Furthermore as students, university information is available and it tells you the different programs they are offering in the different regions. What I enjoyed more about being able to answer this question was looking at the tourist information they have available. Take a look at the Guia turistica de Espana!. Here you have access to information such as a brief version of the history, places to visit and information about the food. Unfortunatelly the only provice available is Madrid, but I'm sure soon enough more information will be available.

    Return to list of questions.

  3. How can you find interesting information within the field of social sciences? Is easy to find information in the field of Social Sciences, is a matter of going into the web's virtual library in Social Sciences and you have more information there than in any other source I have worked with. Social Sciences is a very general field covering anything from Asian Studies and Museums to issues from the United Nations. A topic I was interested in exploring was the United Nations so I linked to the Virtual library United Nations and read about the Red Cross, the Childrens fund in Singapore and trading points.

    Return to list of questions.

  4. How can one create a page to view in Mosaic? Is a simple thing to do. You need to create your document by using HTML (HyperText Markup Language). This is the language the computer will use to interpret what you are telling it. It requires you to follow specific rules to "tag" or "mark" parts in the document. It may at times be frustrating to follow these rules, one missing tag could distort the document but once you learn them, is easy. Another advantage to usng the HTML form is that it is compatible with any browser so anyone can have access to you file being able to retrieve it from any browser not only Mosaic. To learn how to create a HTML document you can access the James Pollell introduction to HTML. Once you read it and learn how to creat the document then you are ready to make your own home page and access it through Mosaic. a demo document for Mosaic!is available. Once you create a document using the web is twice as fun.

    Return to list of questions.

  5. Where can you find sources in Spanish to practice reading as well as learn about other places where the official language is spanish? I have found that most of the sources that you find in the web from another country are in the language of the country that is being presented. I turned my attention in the home page for Latin American Studies her you find a list of different countries that you can explore. For example Argentina! detailed information can be found about the history, geography, government and currency. Is also possible to find out about the current events in the country of choice. For example Mexico in this article you find the different issues Mexico is currently involved in. For example the presidential elections that just passed. This page provides a picture of the candidates as well as an abstract of the issues. Keeping up with current events is hard but keeping up with current events from another country is double the trouble and the web makes it easy.

    Return to list of questions.

Submitted February 08, 1995 for ICS 1C
